channel.title: Unsigned vs. Signed
channel.description: What is the difference between a signed client and unsigned client?

item.title: Unsigned vs. Signed
item.dc:creator: @musicmasta musicmasta
item.description:
@musicmasta wrote:

[quote=“ravekitty, post:5, topic:450654”][quote author=musicmasta link=topic=553538.msg4055818#msg4055818 date=1342929523]
You are not required to sign a jar file that is started from a file that actually exists on your computer. When launching a jar file as a java web-start application, you are required to have the jar file signed, if the file is not signed and run as a web start application, it will restrict it from accessing your computer or network. Signing your jar file is kind of like signing your name on to a sheet of paper, it’s certifying it, giving it the proper authority to run.

To summarize:
Running it as a java web-start application requires the jar to be signed, or it will be restricted from running.
Loading it on your computer will not require the jar to be signed.
[/quote]
http://wiki.eclipse.org/JAR_Signing[/quote]
By this you are trying to tell me?..

Read full topic

item.title: Unsigned vs. Signed
item.dc:creator: @ravekitty ravekitty
item.description:
@ravekitty wrote:

[quote=“musicmasta, post:4, topic:450654”]You are not required to sign a jar file that is started from a file that actually exists on your computer. When launching a jar file as a java web-start application, you are required to have the jar file signed, if the file is not signed and run as a web start application, it will restrict it from accessing your computer or network. Signing your jar file is kind of like signing your name on to a sheet of paper, it’s certifying it, giving it the proper authority to run.

To summarize:
Running it as a java web-start application requires the jar to be signed, or it will be restricted from running.
Loading it on your computer will not require the jar to be signed.[/quote]
http://wiki.eclipse.org/JAR_Signing

Read full topic

item.title: Unsigned vs. Signed
item.dc:creator: @musicmasta musicmasta
item.description:
@musicmasta wrote:

You are not required to sign a jar file that is started from a file that actually exists on your computer. When launching a jar file as a java web-start application, you are required to have the jar file signed, if the file is not signed and run as a web start application, it will restrict it from accessing your computer or network. Signing your jar file is kind of like signing your name on to a sheet of paper, it’s certifying it, giving it the proper authority to run.

To summarize:
Running it as a java web-start application requires the jar to be signed, or it will be restricted from running.
Loading it on your computer will not require the jar to be signed.

Read full topic

item.title: Unsigned vs. Signed
item.dc:creator: @jackabe jackabe
item.description:
@jackabe wrote:

A signed client is used for rsps that you want on your own website. An unsigned can be used for rsps hosters like rsps.com without having to sign it. The hosters only support some bases though.

Read full topic
